SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Then against Tryphon Let us all declare;
The Guards which I have brought my Creatures are,
And I even Long till I his Blood have spilt,
The Victim due both to my Love and Guilt;
We must this Moment kill him by surprise,
Our Safety now in Expedion Lies.
SP.STAGE: Nica. Deme. Aret. and Seleucus goes out.

SP.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SP.L: Sure 'tis the Gods that thus their Hearts Incline.

SP.SPEAKER: Stra.
SP.L: And may the Gods smile too on their designe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SP.L: You both must to the Tyrants Pallace go,
And Let us hourly all that Passes know.
SP.STAGE: Cleopatra, Stratonice, Hermione and Irene goe out.

SP.SPEAKER: Tryphon alone.
SP.L: Demetrius Knowes 'ere now that tis a thing,
Too bold to be a Rival to a King,
And in his Ruine Stratonice shall see
Nothing is dearer then her Love to me,
Nor dare Nicanor my Address detst,
Who by such Proofe he finds I'm not in Jest;
Aretus still so proud A heart did show,
As I long ow'd him what I pay him now;
My faithfull Freed Man Arcas I have sent,
Sooner to learn of my Revenge th' Event.
SP.STAGE: Arcas Runs in hastily and affrighted.

SP.SPEAKER: Arcas,
SP.L: Sir you are lost.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: What makes thee so affraid?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Oh Sir, you by Seleucus are Betray'd.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: This News my Soul do's with Amazement ill.

SP.SPEAKER: Arcas,
SP.L: He's Joyn'd with those whom he was sent to kill?
My hast hath almost robb'd me of my Breath,
And, Sir, with them your Guards conspire your Death;
The People too call for your head aloud,
And to those Traitors in whole troops they croud.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: Arcas, who told this fatal news to thee:

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Sir what I tell you I my self did see,
And through the streets they March'd at such a rate,
As they must now be near the Pallace Gate,
Which is abandon'd, Sir, by all the Guards,
Brib'd by Seleucus Arts or his Rewards;
If you would fly, you should not loose your time.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: Death's but a Punishment, but Flight a Crime,
I'l rather Loose my Life then they shall see
That ought which they can do can frighten me;
The name of King by no base act I'l Blot,
Nor Dying loose the Fame my Life has got.

SP.SPEAKER: Arcas,
SP.L: Were but these Words, Sir, to the Syrians known,
They yet would grant that you deserve the Throne;
To me you seem so Generous and High,
That fighting by your side I mean to Die.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: Dost thou then think I will with Traytors fight?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Sir you disdain to save your self by Flight.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: But who like me a Kingdom did Command,
Should scorn to Die by any Subjects hand;
No, No, he Merits not to fill a Throne
Who when Fate calls, dares not imploy his own;
'Twould be the Traytors Glory as their Guilt,
If they could say that they my Blood had spilt:
Go watch their coming in the outward Roome,
And, when they Enter, say aloud they Come;
Mean while for such a Death I will prepare,
As shall Deserve thy kindness and thy care.
SP.STAGE: Arcas stays weeping and fixes his eyes on Tryphon.
SP.L: Will Arcas then my last Request deny?

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Sir I but begg that I with you may Dye.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: They will surprise me by this fond delay.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: Since you will have it so I must obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: This turn I owe to Cleopatra's Eyes;
Yet since I am depriv'd of Stratonice,
My Death which they united do conspire,
Is not my Fear but that which I Desire.
SP.STAGE: Tryphon goes to an elevated place like a Throne, seats himself in then draws a Ponyard, and viewing it saith,
SP.L: My Hand is yet of this Bright Scepter sure,
Which for my Sufferings is a Certain Cure:
Thus arm'd I will my Enemies outbrave,
And, spight of Fate, deserve a Glorious Grave.
Ah Stratonice, if thou my Heart couldst see,
Thou'dst find I only grieve at leaving thee;
Such Charmes are in thine Eyes.

SP.SPEAKER: Arcas
SP.L: They come, they come.
SP.STAGE: Tryphon rises lifting up his Hand with the Ponyard in it.

SP.SPEAKER: Try.
SP.L: Then I no longer will deferr my Doom.
SP.STAGE: Nicanor, Demetrius, Artus, Seleucus rush in with their Swords drawn, followed by the Guards; All make a stand seeing Try∣phon in that Posture.
SP.L: Though of my Death your Treacheries may boast,
The Triumph yet of your Revenge is lost;
Since Heaven designs this my last hour shall be,
Thus I my self act what the Gods decree:
Pleas'd that my Fate within my own Pow'r lyes,
And that in Death I can my foes despise;
I dye content, since my last breath can boast,
That I your Plot of Murth'ring me have crost.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: The Tyrant with himself has been at strife
To make his Death as Guilty as his Life.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: 'Twas ust this Execution he should doe,
That as he wrong'd us he may right us too.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.L: Yet I must Grieve at that which all Rejoyce,
Death should have been his Punishment, not Choice.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: His thirst of Humane Blood so great was growne,
As he, rather then spare it spilt his owne.
SP.STAGE: One of the Guard leads in Arcas bound.

SP.SPEAKER: Guard,
SP.L: Arcas confesses 'twas he cry'd they come.

SP.SPEAKER: Arc.
SP.L: I do expect, but doe not Fear your Doom.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: Let him in safety to his Country goe.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.L: For our Revenge this Object is too low.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: See how he shakes, Guard let him be unbound.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: We should prize Faithfulness where e'r 'tis found.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.L: To show I merit what I now enjoy,
The Freedome you bestow I thus imploy.
SP.STAGE: Arcas runs to Tryphon, takes the Bloody Poniard which lay by him, and with it stabs himself.
SP.L: That Death you thought I fear'd, I run to meet
And dye content since at-my-Masters—feet

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Arcas deserv'd, who could so bravely Doe,
A better Fate and better Master too.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.L: Tryphon deserved his Gratitude to have,
Him he did free and all the rest enslave.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Arcas I wrong'd thinking he shook for Feare.
SP.STAGE: Enter Cleopatra, Stratonice, Hermione and Irene.

SP.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SP.L: The news of Tryphon's Death hath brought us here,
We heard that he by his own Hand did Dye.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: See where he now Pale as his Guilt does lye.
SP.STAGE: (They all goe towards the dead Body.

SP.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SP.L: This sight at once my Joy and Grief does raise.

SP.SPEAKER: Sra.
SP.L: 'Tis an ignoble Triumph thus to gaze,
Sir, let his Body be from hence convey'd;
He by his Death for all his Crimes has paid.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Since by, the Justice done by Tryphons Hand
The Throne of Syria does now empty stand,
And since the Tyrant; to confirm his sway,
The Royall Line at once did make away,
Princes, 'twere we instantly agreed,
Who is the Worthiest Person to succeed,
And, since his Merit only can pretend,
I judge Nica should the Throne ascend.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: Seleucus you my motion but prevent.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.L: I to whatboth propose with Joy consent,
To you alone the Syri Crown is due.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Excuse me, Sir, it does belong to you.
Admire not that my self I prostrate thus,
Since now I kneel before Antiochus:
Preserv'd by Heaven from Tryphons bloody Pow'r,
To all the blessings of this glorious Hour;
Your Father, Sir, who found he did designe
T'Usurp the Crown and kill the Royall Line,
Sent you that night by a safe hand to me,
Hoping that I shut up in privacy,
(For when the King revoak'd the Generals place
I in Retirement mourn'd out my Disgrace)
Might best protect you from the Tyrants Rage;
This noble Trust did all my Griefs asswage.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: 'Twas a high Proof that he your Virtue knew,
Since whil'st he Wrong'd you he did trust you too.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Out of my House but still within my Care
You by the Gods till now protected were,
Under the name of Le's son you went,
The Prince by whom you first to me were sent,
Who when your Father and the King was kill'd,
O'recome by Greif his Life to Death did yeild;
In reading this short Letter, Sir, you'll know,
Why what you are till now I durst not show.

LETTER.HEAD: Antiochus to Nicanor.
LETTER.L: SInce Heaven this Ruine throwes on us,
Let him by you with Care be bred,
But till you see the Tyrant dead,
(Oh I conjure you grant me this)
Let not himself know who he is,
Th' Affront my Father cast on you forgive,
And let me still in your Remembrance live.

DIV1.STAGE: Aretus gives the Letter to Demetrius and Seleucus.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: If 'tis the Prince's hand, the hand I know,
It is his writing;

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: His subscription too.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: My Testimony were enough alone,
Since I thereby doe gain the Syrian Throne,
To which by all your Votes you would me bring.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: We all acknowledge that you are our King.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.L: Though a lost Crown the Gods to me restore,
Two things there are which yet I value more;
Oh would to Heaven, Seleucus, that I knew
How to be just both to my Love and you.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: Under such loads of Guilt my self I find,
That I though forc'd by Love your Death design'd,
As I the Greatest Sufferings ought to bear,
And therefore yield t' indure the loss of Her;
A hopeless Love to the best End I bring,
Pleasing by it my Mistress and my King;
Bless'd if the Sin caus'd by my Love and Fate
By this Atonement I can expiate.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.L: This Generous Act which now you for me doe
Does most obliege me and Amaze me too.

SP.SPEAKER: To Cleo.
SP.L: Now, Madam, I dare humbly beg of you
To take that Heart which to your Eyes is due,
They make me know that 'tis a greater thing,
To be their Captive then to be their King;
A King who does as his chief Glory own
The Power of laying at your feet a Crown;
In taking it you'l Raise his Joys above
All things except your Beauty and his Love;
Nicanor who to me does Empire give,
I hope will yield that you should let me Live,
Which I shall not till I your Pleasure know.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: The Duty, Sir, she to her King does owe.

SP.SPEAKER: Cleo.
SP.L: That Love for which so Generously you sue,
I give not to your Title but to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.L: Though from your Father I receive a Throne,
Yet now you give me more then he has done;
Amidst these Joys which Heaven on me does send,
I dare not be Unmindful of my Friend;
Demetrius, Sir, Adores Fair Stratonice.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Sir, I with Joy consent that she be his.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: Madam, so Guilty I have been to you,
That I scarce dare for your Forgiveness Sue,
Mercy it self but rarely does bestow
At the same time Rewards and Pardons too.

SP.SPEAKER: Stra. to Dem.
SP.L: Since what you did, Honor did lead you to,
Love shall forgive what Honor made you doe;
And since your Guilt I thus have took away,
Tis fit that I Nicanor should Obey.

SP.SPEAKER: Dem.
SP.L: None by Excess of Joy can Death receive,
Since after this which you have done I live.

SP.SPEAKER: Are. to Nic.
SP.L: Sir, I have now bt one Request to make,
'Tis that the General's Place you now will take,
This is the Lowest Reparation due,
For that affront the King did cason you.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: Since I have liv'd to Place you in the Throne,
The only Duty made me Live is Done.
Besides a Solemn Oath I once did swear,
That I would never Publick Office bear;
Think how Seleucus, Sir, Oblig'd may be,
You have already done too much for me.

SP.SPEAKER: Ar.
SP.L: Then for Seleucus I that place Design,
To which all Tryphon's Forfeitures I joyn;
'Tis just since all our Lives to you we owe,
That you should have the Pow'r to guard them too.

SP.SPEAKER: Sel.
SP.L: These Gifts not for their Greatness I esteem,
But that the Evidence of trust they seem.

SP.SPEAKER: Are. to Nic.
SP.L: Is there then nothing in my Pow'r to doe,
Which, Sir, may show my Gratitude to you.

SP.SPEAKER: Nic.
SP.L: You've given me all the Honor I desir'd:

SP.SPEAKER: Are.
SP.L: You for your self a Nobler have acquir'd.
The Way in which me to the Throne you bring,
Is Greater then to be your self a King.
Now let us to the Gods Oblations pay,
For all the Blessings of this Glorious day:
To them a Double Debt from me is due,
Much for my Crown I owe them, more for You.

LG.L: YOur dealing, we confess, is very faire;
You paid your Money e'r you saw our Ware,
And if you should dislike it now 'tis seen,
I pray how would you get it back again?
Since never yet at Law an Action lay
For Money paid to see a Cry'd-down-Play;
Then whatsoe'r it be, dispraise it not,
But doe as some when they a Clap have got;
Commend the Wench that more to her may goe,
Thus if they Ieer you, you may jeer them too;
New Playes, like Wives, are subject to the curse
Of being took for better or for worse.

DIV1.HEAD: ERRATA in the Black Prince.
DIV1.P: PAge 1. Line 7. read prais'd, for priz'd. l. 16. r. Frenchmens, for frenchmans. p 3. l. 18. r. for, for from. l. 25. r. made, for rail'd. l. 42. r. Eyes, for Eye. l. 36. r. belief, for releif. p. 50 l. 1. r. DIV1.HEAD: ERRATA in Tryphon.
DIV1.P: PAge 1. l. 13. r. and he too much deserves. l. 20. r. this Monster's wickedness. l. 28. r. it, for, he. l. 31. r. guilt, for blood. p. 2. l. 19. r. worse, for more. l. 24. r. it, for even. p. 3. l. 2. r. you'll, r will. p. 7 l. 22. r. his sorrow is but his hypocrisy. l. 43. r▪ what Try∣phon ere shall doe. p. 10. l. 44. r. 'tis worse then death. p. 12. l. 13. r. now, for well. p. 14. l. 15. r. 'tis., for 'tw. l. 17. r. not Aretus Arme employ. p. 17. l. 32. r. much, for sad. p. 20. l. 39. r. for, for. so. p. 21. l. 35. r. which did betwixtus pass. p. 23. l. 40. r. for, for in. p. 24. l. 10. r. hand, for man. p. 25. l. 1. cries, for crimes. l. 21. r. said, for done. l. 38. r. help. for self. p 26. l. 21. r the, for your. l. 24. r. or, for e're. p. 29. l. 26. r. makes, for made. l. 17. r. truth, for faith. l. 31. r. and, for yet. l 38. r. are, for be. p. 30. l. 4. r. beare, for fear'. l. 29 r. that, for this. p. 31. l. 8. r. me, for you. p. 32. l. 19. r. you, for them. l 25. r. decline, for resigne. l. 29. r. too, for 'twas. p. 33. l. 1. r. of, for for. l. 8. r. thereby, for therein. p. 34. l. 11. r. for, for . l. 25. r. of a more sharp revenge. l. 38. r. lowest, for bra∣vest. p. 35. l. 38. r. love, for same. p. 37. l. 1. r. for, for from. l. 30. r. hate, for curse. p. 38. l. 10. r. my, for such. l. 18 r. wounds, for words. p. 39. l. 23. r. it, for her. p. 40. l. 42. r. act, for aske. p. 41. l. 16. r. what, for why. p. 41. l. 29. r. just. for best. p. 43. l. 28. r. tyrnts may life. l. . r. same, for name. l. 16. r. mine, for it. p. 44. l. 21. r. prove, for grow. p. 45. l. 27. r. we justy should repine. l. 36. r. can, for should. l. 31. r. could, for would. p. 46. l. 10. r. with, for . p. 47. l. 17. r. wept, for went. p. 49. l. 37. r. Case, for losse. p. 50. l. 1. r. where, for when. p. 52. l 25. r. they, for you. p. 53. l. 10. r. loosing, for leaving. p. 55. l. 8. r. Ze∣no's son, for Leno's son. p. 56. l. 6. r. loose, for gaine. l. 22. r. both, for most. l. 26. r. , for their. l. 34. r. that, for t.
